José Luis Picardo, a Spanish architect and artist, was born in Jerez de la Frontera in 1919. After his father's death in 1929, he moved to Madrid and studied law and architecture, but his education was disrupted by the Spanish Civil War. He began his architecture studies in 1945 and, due to his painting and drawing abilities, was commissioned to create murals and illustrations for architectural magazines. His first professional mural painting was completed in 1939 at the Cine Fígaro in Madrid.

Picardo focused on historical architecture in his early career, collaborating with architect Fernando Chueca Goitia on preservation and restoration projects. He was a signatory of the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" in 1952, advocating for a Spanish modern architecture inspired by the Alhambra in Granada.

Throughout the 1950s, Picardo entered architectural competitions and designed various buildings, including a center for the Cofradía de Pescadores in Altea, a small hotel on the Costa del Sol, and an apartment building near Madrid's Plaza de Las Ventas. He also worked on the Spanish Ministerio de Información y Turismo's Paradores de Turismo de España project in the 1960s and 1970s.

As an artist, Picardo created decorative mural paintings and illustrations for a best-selling textbook on Spanish architecture. He received an unusual commission in 1959 to design a Loewe fashion brand playing card pack and another games design for wooden chess pieces. The Dirección General de Arquitectura recognized his contributions with the publication of "Dibujos de José Luis Picardo" in 1960.

José Luis Picardo was highly regarded as a muralist and architect, with his drawings of buildings and architectural details featured in a popular textbook on Spanish architecture. In 1959, he was commissioned to design a Loewe fashion brand playing card pack and a set of wooden chess pieces. His contributions to architecture were recognized by the Dirección General de Arquitectura with the publication of "Dibujos de José Luis Picardo" in 1960. From the early 1960s to 1985, Picardo dedicated much of his professional life to the Paradores de Turismo de España project, restoring and converting historic buildings into luxury hotels. His work for Paradores is highly regarded and has influenced other architects in Spain and Portugal.

At Guadalupe, Picardo converted two ancient buildings into a Parador, preserving their original Mudéjar style and using ancient construction techniques. He set the main hospitality section in the Colegio de Infantes, adding to the external south side to provide a dining room and guest rooms. The Hospital de San Juan Bautista was remodeled for the hotel's kitchens, service areas, and staff residences. Picardo also designed much of the furniture and internal decoration, making use of decorative wall tiles produced by the ceramicist Juan Manuel Arroyo Ruiz de Luna.

In Jaén, Picardo was commissioned to design and build a Parador at the Castillo de Santa Catalina. He planned a simple hostería with a dining room, lounge, service accommodation, and guest rooms on the location of the old barracks and stables of the castle. Building in the castle would have meant making substantial openings in the original walls or building above the height of the battlements, which Picardo found unacceptable.

José Luis Picardo was commissioned to design and build a Parador at the Castillo de Santa Catalina in Jaén, Spain, in the early 1960s. He chose to build the hostería on the site of the old barracks and stables, rather than in the castle itself, due to his desire to preserve the original walls and battlements. The building was designed in a simple style, with large windows to enjoy the views, and was constructed using modern materials hidden by traditional ones to give the appearance of age. The first phase of the building, completed in 1965, included 7 double guest rooms, a cafetería, a bar, a reception area, a lounge, a restaurant, and service areas. Picardo added service rooms and 12 more guest rooms in 1969, and a further extension with 24 guest rooms in 1973, bringing the total to 43. The building was elevated to the title of Parador when the extension was completed in 1978. Picardo also designed the interior, producing furniture, wall-hangings, shutters, carpets, light fittings, door furniture, floor and wall tile patterns, and coats of arms from demolished buildings for both the interior and exterior of the Parador. He used hand-painted written ceramic tiles to decorate and 'sign' the building, and to expound on its history and to credit the surveyor and stoneworker.

José Luis Picardo undertook several projects in the 1960s and 1970s, including the design and construction of a Parador in Jaén, which was built in phases and expanded from 7 to 43 guest rooms. He also designed the interior, incorporating traditional Andalucían features and ceramic tiles for decoration and explanatory texts. In Pedraza, he restored the Casa de la Inquisición, turning it into a hostería with a rustic style, but the plan to expand it with neighboring buildings didn't materialize. The Pedraza Hostería operated until 1992. At Alcañiz, Picardo converted the Palacio de los Comendadores into a Parador with 12 guest rooms, preserving the medieval design on the ground floor and making the upper floors more palatial. He also designed the interior decoration, incorporating the emblem of the Order of Calatrava. In 1975, he designed a new two-story wing to double the number of guest rooms, which was completed in 1998. In Cáceres, Picardo worked on the Palacio del Comendador de Alcúescar, converting part of it into a Hostería, which was built in a jumble of old buildings, mostly stables and coach houses, and featured a sgraffito image above the main doorway.

In the 1960s and 1970s, José Luis Picardo undertook several projects, including the conversion of existing buildings into Paradores and hosterías. In Cáceres, he transformed part of a 15th-century palace into a hostería, preserving its medieval design while adding new elements. He also built a new wing with additional guest rooms in 1975. The palace was originally a medieval fortified residence, which had been modified over centuries with the addition of Gothic, Renaissance, and Baroque elements. Picardo chose a jumble of old buildings, mostly stables and coach houses, to convert into the hostería. He preserved some of the existing structures and added new ones, using terracotta tiles, heavy timber, and medieval-style designs for windows, doors, furniture, and light fittings. The hostería opened in 1971, and Picardo later completed additional work on the palace, including re-roofing and extending the original dining room area. The hostería was eventually closed in 1984 and the rest of the palace was converted into a full Parador with 27 guest rooms. Picardo's original entrance, bar, and cafeteria area now form a suite in the Parador.

In 1966, Picardo was commissioned to inspect three ancient sites near Sevilla with a view to constructing another Parador. He chose the Alcázar del Rey Don Pedro in Carmona, a ruined castle from the 14th century, and began his preparatory work in 1968. The castle had been severely damaged in earthquakes and most of its connecting walls were in ruins. Picardo chose the southeast of the vast castle area, a corner known as the Plaza de Armas, to build the Parador. He designed a typical Hispanic-Arabic layout with two central patios, one for the public area and the other for the service department. The building was constructed in vernacular form and appeared to be historic, with four floors on the south and east walls and two floors on the parade ground entrance side. The main structure of the building was formed of concrete, clad with ashlar and brickwork, and enhanced by buttresses. The Carmona Parador was inaugurated on 30 March 197

In the 1970s, José Luis Picardo converted a ruined castle in Carmona into a Parador, maintaining a Hispanic-Arabic style with terracotta tiles, ceramic tiling, and brick. He designed the building with a typical layout, including two central patios and four floors with a concrete structure. The castle was initially severely damaged and had to undergo underpinning and other structural work due to movement in the ground. The castle was eventually converted into a Parador with 9 double rooms, 51 twin rooms, and 3 single rooms. Picardo also worked on the Castillo de Sigüenza, a comprehensively ruined palace-fortress, where he resolved to remodel it as totally medieval, removing all later additions and restoring the military feeling of the castle with towers and battlements. He raised the outer walls and removed large windows, balconies, and other wide openings, and cleared the central courtyard of all post-medieval accretions. The interior was reconstructed using modern elements hidden behind a historical veneer.

In the 1960s and 1970s, architect José Luis Picardo was tasked with converting old buildings into Paradores, public hotels run by the Spanish government. He worked on the Castillo de Sigüenza, where he maintained a medieval aesthetic by minimizing exterior windows and adding many courtyard window openings. He also preserved some original features while reconstructing others in a historical style. Picardo's work aimed to create a convincing historical atmosphere for tourists, sometimes at the expense of historical accuracy. His approach has been criticized by some archaeologists and historians, who argue that his rebuilding projects were not based on thorough archaeological research and that they involved the demolition of significant parts of monumental buildings. Despite these criticisms, Picardo's work has also been praised for its artistic value and its contribution to Spain's tourism industry.

He aimed to create a historical atmosphere for tourists, often prioritizing this goal over historical accuracy. His work, including his conversion of the Castillo de Sigüenza, involved minimal exterior windows, many courtyard window openings, and the preservation or reconstruction of original features in a historical style. Picardo's rebuilding projects were primarily based on his own historical and architectural research, with new extensions designed to resemble the monuments to which they were attached. His work has been described as "false history" and a "convincing set design" to evoke the historical era of interest to tourists, often the medieval period. This approach, while controversial among historians, has resulted in popular hotels, such as those at Jäen, Carmona, and Sigüenza.

Throughout his career, Picardo also carried out restoration works on various historical buildings, including the Catedral de Cádiz, Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe, Catedral de Santa María de Sigüenza, Ermita del Humilladero, Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana, Palacio de Gamazo, Castillo de San Felipe, and Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca. His design for the Fundación Juan March headquarters in Madrid, completed in 1975, is considered one of his best works, showcasing his ability to control proportions and spaces with ease.

In 1978, José Luis Picardo received a commission from the Ministry of Information and Tourism to construct a public indoor riding arena for the Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre in Jerez de la Frontera, Spain, which was his birthplace. The arena, designed in a neo-Renaissance style, featured a deep ochre exterior representing the local land and soil, and stark white interior reflecting traditional Andalusian village homes. It could seat up to 1,600 spectators, had stable facilities for 60 horses, and was opened for performances in 1980. Picasso's Guernica painting was installed in the Museo Nacional del Prado in 1981, and Picardo, along with architect José García María de Paredes, designed a protective armored glass and steel display for it. Picardo was elected to the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in 1997 and gifted the academy his oil painting Guardia civil en el puerto de Alazores in 2000. He won the Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura in 2001 for his architectural contributions. Picardo passed away in Madrid in 2010.
